biography.name: Dr. Carlos E. Cortés
biography.title: Edward A. Dickson Emeritus Professor of History
biography.bio: Dr. Carlos E. Cortés is a pioneering figure in multicultural education, ethnic studies, and diversity scholarship with a career spanning seven decades. Born in 1934 in Kansas City, Missouri, he grew up navigating the intersection of cultures as the son of Carlos Cortés, a Mexican Catholic immigrant from Guadalajara, and Florence Hoffman, a Jewish American mother. After earning degrees from UC Berkeley, Columbia, and the University of New Mexico, he began his career as a history professor at UC Riverside in 1968 and has since become one of the most influential voices in American diversity education.
biography.personal_background: In 1933, Carlos Cortés's father, a Mexican Catholic immigrant from Guadalajara, married Florence Hoffman, a Jewish American woman—an intermarriage before its time. Growing up in post-WWII Kansas City, young Carlos learned to navigate multiple identities. A defining moment came in 1949 when, as a sophomore, he was pressured by a Spanish teacher to go by 'Carl' instead of Carlos. His father stormed to the principal's office declaring: 'My son's name is Carlos. His father's name is Carlos. His grandfather's name was Carlos. His great-grandfather's name was Carlos. And I'll be damned if you're going to call him anything but Carlos.' This became a touchstone for authentic inclusivity throughout his career. He later wrote about these experiences in his memoir 'Rose Hill: An Intermarriage before Its Time' (2012) and adapted it into a one-person play performed nationwide.

entries.title: Editor, Blue and Gold Yearbook, UC Berkeley
entries.description: Served as editor of Blue and Gold, the University of California, Berkeley yearbook. This student leadership role launched his career in communications and publishing.

entries.title: Chair, Student Publications Board, UC Berkeley
entries.description: Chaired the Student Publications Board at the University of California, Berkeley. Oversaw campus publications and editorial operations as an undergraduate leader.

entries.title: B.A., Communications and Public Policy (Phi Beta Kappa), UC Berkeley
entries.description: Graduated from the University of California, Berkeley with a B.A. in Communications and Public Policy. Inducted into Phi Beta Kappa for outstanding academic achievement.

entries.title: M.S., Journalism, Columbia Graduate School of Journalism
entries.description: Earned a Master of Science in Journalism from Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. The Ivy League training grounded his lifelong commitment to clear, accessible communication.

entries.title: Press Assistant, American Shakespeare Festival, Stratford, Connecticut
entries.description: Served as press assistant for the American Shakespeare Festival in Stratford, Connecticut. Applied his journalism training to arts communications and public relations.

entries.title: Public Information Specialist, Fort Gordon, Georgia
entries.description: Served as a Public Information Specialist at Fort Gordon, Georgia. Military service provided experience in institutional communications and public affairs.

entries.title: Editor, Phoenix Sunpapers, Phoenix, Arizona
entries.description: Worked as editor of the Phoenix Sunpapers in Phoenix, Arizona. This professional journalism experience preceded his pivot to academic life and graduate study in history.

entries.title: Bachelor of Foreign Trade, American Institute for Foreign Trade
entries.description: Earned a Bachelor of Foreign Trade from the American Institute for Foreign Trade in Glendale, Arizona. This degree reflected his growing interest in international affairs and Latin America.

entries.title: M.A., Portuguese, University of New Mexico
entries.description: Completed a Master of Arts in Portuguese at the University of New Mexico. Language training prepared him for doctoral research on Brazilian politics.

entries.title: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Brazil (Ford Foundation Fellowship)
entries.description: Conducted doctoral dissertation research in Brazil with a Ford Foundation Foreign Area Fellowship. Field research on regional politics in Rio Grande do Sul became the basis for his first book.

entries.title: Began Career as History Professor at UCR
entries.description: Began his career as a history professor at the University of California, Riverside. This appointment launched what would become a 57-year association with UCR.

entries.title: Ph.D., History, University of New Mexico
entries.description: Received his Ph.D. in History from the University of New Mexico. His dissertation examined regional politics in southern Brazil during the mid-twentieth century.

entries.title: Co-founded Mexican American Studies Program at UCR
entries.description: Member of the committee that designed and founded the Mexican American Studies Program (later renamed Chicano Studies) at UCR. Helped establish one of the early ethnic studies programs in the UC system.

entries.title: Taught UCR's First Chicano History Course
entries.description: Taught UCR's first Chicano History course, pioneering the development of Chicano Studies as an academic discipline at UC Riverside. The course examined the historical experiences of Mexican Americans from the colonial period through the contemporary Chicano movement.

entries.title: Chair, UCR Latin American Studies Program
entries.description: Became chair of UCR's Latin American Studies program, serving until 1972. Provided academic leadership in an area of growing scholarly and policy interest.

entries.title: Ethnic Content Textbook Task Force, California State Department of Education
entries.description: Served on the Ethnic Content Textbook Task Force of the California State Department of Education. This first state-level effort to evaluate textbooks for ethnic representation helped establish standards that influenced textbook publishing nationwide.

entries.title: Chair, UCR Mexican American Studies Program
entries.description: Became chair of UCR's Mexican American Studies Program (later renamed Chicano Studies), serving until 1979. Led the program through a formative period of growth and institutionalization.

entries.title: Co-produced Documentary 'Northwest from Tumacácori'
entries.description: Co-produced and co-authored the historical documentary film 'Northwest from Tumacácori.' This early media work demonstrated his interest in reaching audiences beyond academia through visual storytelling.

entries.title: 'Teaching the Chicano Experience' in Teaching Ethnic Studies
entries.description: Contributed the chapter 'Teaching the Chicano Experience' to James Banks's influential volume Teaching Ethnic Studies: Concepts and Strategies. When Banks's book became widely adopted for teacher training, Cortés found himself launched onto the national speakers' circuit for K-12 multicultural education.

entries.title: Gaúcho Politics in Brazil: The Politics of Rio Grande do Sul, 1930-1964
entries.description: Published his first book, a scholarly monograph examining regional politics in Brazil's southernmost state. Received the Hubert Herring Memorial Award of the Pacific Coast Council on Latin American Studies; published in Brazil in 2007 as Política Gaúcha.

entries.title: Edited The Mexican American, The Chicano Heritage, and Hispanics in the United States Reprint Series
entries.description: Edited The Mexican American (a 21-volume book reprint series) for Arno Press, followed in 1976 by The Chicano Heritage (55 volumes) and in 1980 by Hispanics in the United States (30 volumes). These curated reprint series made key scholarship accessible to new generations of researchers and students.

entries.title: Co-organized First California Statewide Bilingual Education Conference
entries.description: Co-organized the first California statewide bilingual education conference at UCR. The conference led to the formation of the California Association for Bilingual Education (CABE).

entries.title: UCR Distinguished Teaching Award
entries.description: Received the UCR Distinguished Teaching Award. Recognized for excellence in the classroom during a period of pioneering curricular innovation at UC Riverside.

entries.title: Co-edited Three Perspectives on Ethnicity: Blacks, Chicanos, and Native Americans
entries.description: Co-edited an anthology examining ethnicity through the distinct lenses of African American, Chicano, and Native American experiences. One of the earliest scholarly efforts to analyze ethnic identity across multiple groups within a single analytical framework.

entries.title: 'The Societal Curriculum and the School Curriculum: Allies or Antagonists?'
entries.description: Published the influential article introducing the concept of the 'societal curriculum' — the informal education that occurs through media, institutions, and social interactions outside formal schooling. Widely adopted in multicultural education literature, the concept helped educators understand their work within larger social contexts.

entries.title: Distinguished California Humanist Award
entries.description: Received the Distinguished California Humanist Award from the California Council for the Humanities. Recognized his contributions to public understanding of culture and diversity.

entries.title: 'Mexicans' in Harvard Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups
entries.description: Wrote the essay 'Mexicans,' published in the Harvard Encyclopedia of American Ethnic Groups. Contributed an authoritative overview of Mexican American history and culture to a landmark reference work.

entries.title: Began Teaching History of the Mass Media at UCR
entries.description: Began teaching an annual course, History of the Mass Media, at UCR. This new teaching focus marked the beginning of his sustained engagement with media literacy and media's role in shaping public understanding of diversity.

entries.title: UCR History Department Chair
entries.description: Became UCR History Department chair, serving from 1982 to 1986. Provided departmental leadership during a period of growth in ethnic studies and interdisciplinary scholarship.

entries.title: Guest Presenter, PBS 'Why in the World?'
entries.description: Became a periodic guest presenter on the PBS national series 'Why in the World?,' making three appearances through 1984. Brought his diversity education expertise to mainstream public television audiences.

entries.title: Bildner Fellow, Association of American Schools in South America
entries.description: Served as the Bildner Fellow of the Association of American Schools in South America. Extended his multicultural education work into international contexts across the Americas.

entries.title: Wrote PBS Documentary 'Latinos: A Growing Voice in U.S. Politics'
entries.description: Wrote the PBS documentary 'Latinos: A Growing Voice in U.S. Politics.' Brought scholarly analysis of Latino political participation to a national television audience.

entries.title: Columnist, Media & Values Magazine
entries.description: Began as a columnist for the magazine Media & Values: A Quarterly Review of Media Issues and Trends, continuing until 1990. Wrote regularly on media's role in shaping attitudes about diversity and stereotypes.

entries.title: Helped Establish Costo Chair and Costo Library at UCR
entries.description: Helped establish the Rupert and Jeannette Costo Chair in American Indian History and the Costo Library of the American Indian in the UCR Library's Special Collections. Contributed to building institutional infrastructure for Native American studies at UCR.

entries.title: Co-authored Beyond Language: Social and Cultural Factors in Schooling Language Minority Students
entries.description: Co-authored this influential California State Department of Education publication examining social and cultural factors affecting language minority students. Presented a 'contextual interaction model' that influenced bilingual education policy and practice.

entries.title: Japan Foundation Fellow
entries.description: Spent four weeks in Japan as a Japan Foundation Fellow. Broadened his international perspective on how societies address cultural diversity and intercultural communication.

entries.title: Edited 'Images and Realities of Four World Regions'
entries.description: Edited this curriculum examining global perspectives and challenging stereotypes about world regions. Extended multicultural education concepts into international contexts.

entries.title: Faculty, Harvard Summer Institutes for Higher Education
entries.description: Became a faculty member of the Harvard Summer Institutes for Higher Education. Brought his multicultural education expertise to Harvard's professional development programs for higher education leaders.

entries.title: Consultant, Japanese National Chamber of Commerce
entries.description: Served as consultant for the Japanese National Chamber of Commerce. Applied his intercultural expertise to improving business communication and cultural understanding between Japanese and American organizations.

entries.title: Advisory Committee, 'Talking with TJ' (Hallmark Foundation)
entries.description: Began service on the advisory committee for 'Talking with TJ,' a Hallmark Foundation youth conflict resolution media series. Contributed diversity expertise to children's media programming.

entries.title: 'The Man Masks of Multicultural Education' Lecture at UCLA
entries.description: Gave the lecture 'The Man Masks of Multicultural Education' at a conference at the University of California, Los Angeles. Addressed challenges and contradictions in the multicultural education movement.

entries.title: UCR Faculty Public Service Award
entries.description: Received the UCR Faculty Public Service Award. Recognized for his extensive community engagement and public contributions beyond traditional academic work.

entries.title: National Panel, AAC American Commitments Project
entries.description: Appointed to the National Panel of the Association of American Colleges project, American Commitments: Diversity, Democracy, and Liberal Learning. Helped shape national conversations about diversity in higher education.

entries.title: Featured Presenter, Video Journal of Education's 'Diversity in the Classroom'
entries.description: Featured presenter for the Video Journal of Education's series 'Diversity in the Classroom.' The educational training video became widely used in teacher preparation programs nationwide.

entries.title: Took Early Retirement from the University of California
entries.description: Took early retirement from the University of California. Far from slowing down, his post-retirement career proved to be among his most productive decades.

entries.title: Faculty, Summer Institute for Intercultural Communication
entries.description: Became a faculty member of the Summer Institute for Intercultural Communication. Contributed to training professionals in cross-cultural competence and dialogue facilitation.

entries.title: Lecture Tour of Australian Universities
entries.description: Conducted a lecture tour of Australian universities. Extended his multicultural education work to international audiences grappling with their own diversity challenges.

entries.title: Faculty, Federal Executive Institute
entries.description: Became a faculty member of the Federal Executive Institute. Brought diversity education to senior federal government leaders and administrators.

entries.title: Founding Coordinator, Riverside Mayor's Multicultural Forum
entries.description: Became the founding coordinator of the Riverside, California, Mayor's Multicultural Forum. Established an ongoing civic institution for community dialogue about diversity and inclusion.

entries.title: Faculty, University of Maryland Civicus Living-Learning Program
entries.description: Became a faculty member of the Department of Resident Life and Civicus Living-Learning Program at the University of Maryland, College Park. Contributed to an innovative residential program integrating civic engagement with academic study.

entries.title: The Children Are Watching: How the Media Teach about Diversity
entries.description: Published this groundbreaking analysis of how mass media — television, film, news, advertising — educate viewers about diversity. The book established Cortés as a leading voice in understanding media's pedagogical function and is widely cited in both diversity education and media studies.

entries.title: Creative/Cultural Advisor, Nickelodeon's Dora the Explorer
entries.description: Became consultant (later Creative/Cultural Advisor) for Nickelodeon's Dora the Explorer television series, also serving on Go, Diego, Go!, Dora and Friends: Into the City, and Santiago of the Seas. Championed making Dora 'pan-Latino' — a proud Latina without specific national origin — so Latino children of all backgrounds could identify with her.

entries.title: Outstanding Contribution to Higher Education Award, NASPA
entries.description: Received the Outstanding Contribution to Higher Education Award from the National Association of Student Personnel Administrators. Recognized his decades of work improving diversity practices across colleges and universities.

entries.title: Riverside Inclusive Community Statement
entries.description: Facilitated and wrote the Riverside, California, Inclusive Community Statement. Articulated core principles for building an inclusive community that embraced diversity as a civic strength.

entries.title: The Making — and Remaking — of a Multiculturalist
entries.description: Published this autobiographical educational memoir tracing his personal and professional journey in multicultural education. The book demonstrates how his personal story mirrors the larger trajectory of the multicultural education movement.

entries.title: First Performance of 'A Conversation with Alana'
entries.description: First performance of his one-person autobiographical play, 'A Conversation with Alana: One Boy's Multicultural Rite of Passage.' The play has since been performed approximately 160 times at universities and educational institutions across the United States.

entries.title: UCR Emeritus Faculty Award
entries.description: Received the UCR Emeritus Faculty Award. Recognized for continued scholarly contributions after retirement from active teaching.

entries.title: Co-authored Houghton Mifflin and McDougal Littell Textbook Series
entries.description: Co-authored Houghton Mifflin's K-6 Social Studies textbook series and McDougal Littell World History textbook series. Brought multicultural perspectives to mainstream educational materials reaching millions of students.

entries.title: 'After the Rain: Tomás Rivera — The Legacy and Life'
entries.description: Wrote, narrated, and co-produced the documentary 'After the Rain: Tomás Rivera — The Legacy and Life.' Honored the legacy of the pioneering Chicano author and former UC chancellor.

entries.title: Honorary Doctorate, College of Wooster
entries.description: Received an honorary doctorate from the College of Wooster. Recognized for his distinguished contributions to multicultural education and diversity scholarship.

entries.title: NAACP Image Award
entries.description: Received the NAACP Image Award for his Creative/Cultural Advisory work on Nickelodeon programs. The award acknowledged his contributions to positive representation of people of color in children's media.

entries.title: Honorary Doctorate, DePaul University
entries.description: Received an honorary doctorate from DePaul University in Chicago. His second honorary degree recognized his national impact on diversity education and intercultural dialogue.

entries.title: Co-authored Musical 'We Are Not Alone: Tomás Rivera'
entries.description: Co-authored the book and lyrics and co-produced (with Juan Felipe Rivera) the musical 'We Are Not Alone: Tomás Rivera, a Musical Narrative,' with music by Bruno Louchouarn. Extended his creative work into musical theater honoring a Chicano literary icon.

entries.title: Rose Hill: An Intermarriage before Its Time
entries.description: Published this memoir about growing up as the son of a Mexican Catholic father and Jewish American mother in post-WWII Kansas City. Adapted from his nationally performed one-person play, the book foregrounds the famous 'Carl moment' when his father defended his Mexican name.

entries.title: Editor, Multicultural America: A Multimedia Encyclopedia (4 volumes)
entries.description: Edited the four-volume Multicultural America Encyclopedia for SAGE Publications, containing more than 900 entries from scholars across disciplines. Among the first major reference works to extensively use 2010 U.S. Census data to analyze multiculturalism.

entries.title: AMPAS Project for Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA
entries.description: Member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences project for Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA, Latin American and Latino Art in LA. Contributed his media expertise to a major arts initiative celebrating Latino contributions.

entries.title: Carlos E. Cortés Diversity and Inclusion Award Established
entries.description: The City of Riverside established the Carlos E. Cortés Diversity and Inclusion Award. The first award of its kind in Riverside honors individuals who embody his values of bridge-building inclusion.

entries.title: Named Edward A. Dickson Emeritus Professor, UCR
entries.description: Named Edward A. Dickson Emeritus Professor at the University of California, Riverside. This distinguished endowed title recognized his exceptional post-retirement contributions to scholarship and public service.

entries.title: Fourth Quarter: Reflections of a Cranky Old Man
entries.description: Published his first book of poetry, reflecting on life as an octogenarian with wit and unflinching honesty. Received Honorable Mention in the International Latino Book Awards competition for Best Book of Poetry.

entries.title: Inaugural Fellow, UC National Center for Free Speech and Civic Engagement
entries.description: Named an inaugural fellow of the University of California National Center for Free Speech and Civic Engagement. Researched how colleges and universities navigate tensions between free expression and diversity commitments.

entries.title: Columnist, American Diversity Report
entries.description: Became a columnist for the ezine American Diversity Report, writing two series: 'Diversity and Speech' and 'Renewing Diversity.' The columns explore the intersection of diversity advocacy and free expression.

entries.title: Played 'Big Bad Wolf' in LA Reading of 'The Shit Show'
entries.description: Played the 'Big Bad Wolf' in a Los Angeles public reading of 'The Shit Show' by Leelee Jackson. Demonstrated his continuing enthusiasm for theatrical performance and creative collaboration.

entries.title: Initial Draft of Ethnic Studies Curriculum Principles for California
entries.description: Drafted an initial statement of suggested principles for high school Ethnic Studies curricula at the request of the California State Board of Education. His principles were adapted into the final Model Curriculum adopted in March 2021, contributing to California becoming the first state to require ethnic studies for graduation.

entries.title: Riverside Anti-Racism Vision Statement
entries.description: Coordinated development and wrote a two-page anti-racism vision statement for the City of Riverside, adopted 6-1 by City Council on October 20, 2020. The creation process exemplified his commitment to transparent, community-inclusive methods.

entries.title: Co-director, HESJAR Curriculum, UCR School of Medicine
entries.description: Appointed co-director (with Dr. Adwoa Osei) of the Health Equity, Social Justice, and Anti-Racism curricular thread of the UC Riverside School of Medicine. Brought 50+ years of diversity education expertise to medical education.

entries.title: Cultural Advisor, Nickelodeon's Santiago of the Seas
entries.description: Served as Cultural Advisor for Nickelodeon's Santiago of the Seas animated series. Extended his two decades of cultural consulting for Nickelodeon to a new generation of bilingual children's programming.

entries.title: Constantine Panunzio Distinguished Emeriti Award
entries.description: Received the Constantine Panunzio Distinguished Emeriti Award, the University of California's highest honor for emeriti faculty. Became the first faculty member from UC Riverside to receive this prestigious UC-wide recognition.

entries.title: Consulting Humanist, Cheech Marin Center for Chicano Art and Culture
entries.description: Became Consulting Humanist for the Cheech Marin Center for Chicano Art and Culture in Riverside. Conducts filmed 'Conversations at The Cheech' exploring Chicano art and culture with artists and community members.

entries.title: A Conversation with Alana: One Boy's Multicultural Rite of Passage (Published Book)
entries.description: Published his one-person autobiographical play as a book. Made the widely performed theatrical work accessible to readers beyond the live performance circuit.

entries.title: Teachers Pay Teachers Content Moderation Task Force
entries.description: Appointed to the Teachers Pay Teachers Content Moderation Task Force. Brought his diversity expertise to shaping content standards for one of the largest teacher resource platforms.

entries.title: Cultural Consultant, 'Puss in Boots: The Last Wish' (DreamWorks)
entries.description: Served as cultural consultant for DreamWorks Animation's Academy Award-nominated 'Puss in Boots: The Last Wish.' Continued his pattern of ensuring authentic Latino cultural representation in mainstream entertainment.

entries.title: 'Renewing Multicultural Education: An Ancient Mariner's Manifesto'
entries.description: Published this influential article in Multicultural Perspectives, adapted from his 2024 NAME conference keynote. Called for returning to the founding principles of 1970s multicultural education: bridge-building inclusion, uninhibited dialogue, and optimistic vision.

entries.title: Scouts' Honor (Novel)
entries.description: Published his debut novel, a mystery set at Boy Scout Camp Matulia in southwestern Missouri. His first venture into long-form fiction at age 91, drawing inspiration from his own summer camp experience.

entries.title: Contributing Author, Creating the Intercultural Field: Legacies from the Pioneers
entries.description: Contributing author to Creating the Intercultural Field: Legacies from the Pioneers. Reflected on his role as a founding figure in intercultural education and diversity scholarship.

entries.title: Multilingual Educator Hall of Fame, NABE
entries.description: Inducted into the Multilingual Educator Hall of Fame by the National Association for Bilingual Education. Recognized for his lifelong contributions to bilingual and multicultural education, spanning from co-founding CABE in 1975 to the present.
